stem: Based on the findings, which action should the nurse take FIRST?

options.text: Immediately stop the blood transfusion and disconnect the IV tubing.
Administer diphenhydramine intravenously per standing order.
Collect a urine specimen and send it to the laboratory.
Slow the transfusion rate and closely monitor the patient's vital signs.

tabs.name: SBAR
tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
07:00, I am calling about Jane Doe, a 62-year-old female in room 302 who is receiving a blood transfusion. She started the transfusion of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) about 30 minutes ago. 

Her BP has dropped from 130/80 to 90/50, HR increased from 80 to 120, and she reports chills and lower back pain. She appears anxious and diaphoretic. Her temperature is now 38.9°C (102°F), up from 37°C (98.6°F) prior to the transfusion. 

I am concerned she is having an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction. I have stopped the transfusion, but I need further orders. She has a history of osteoarthritis and no known allergies. 

I recommend we draw blood for a transfusion reaction workup, administer IV fluids, and monitor her urine output. Would you like any additional information or have any further orders at this time?

tabs.name: Vitals
tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content:
06:30: BP 130/80, HR 80, RR 18, Temp 37°C (98.6°F), SpO2 98% on room air.
07:00: BP 90/50, HR 120, RR 24, Temp 38.9°C (102°F), SpO2 92% on room air.

tabs.name: Labs
tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content:
Pre-Transfusion: Type O, Rh-positive. Antibody screen: Negative. 
Current: Blood sample sent for STAT repeat type and crossmatch, direct antiglobulin test (DAT), and blood culture.

tabs.name: Exam
tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Anxious, diaphoretic.
Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, weak peripheral pulses.
Respiratory: Increased respiratory rate, lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Integumentary: Skin flushed.
Neurological: Alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Complaining of lower back pain.

tabs.name: Orders
tabs.title: Orders
tabs.content:
06:00: Transfuse 1 unit of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) over 2 hours. Monitor vital signs every 15 minutes during the first hour, then every 30 minutes. 
07:05: Normal saline at 100 mL/hr. Furosemide 20 mg IV STAT. Diphenhydramine 50 mg IV PRN for itching.

tabs.name: MAR
tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
06:30: PRBC transfusion initiated.
06:30: Normal Saline 100mL/hr initiated.

rationale.correct: Stopping the transfusion is the priority action when a hemolytic transfusion reaction is suspected. This prevents further exposure to the incompatible blood, which can lead to severe complications such as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and acute kidney injury. Disconnecting the IV tubing prevents any residual blood from entering the patient's circulation. Immediate intervention is crucial to minimize the severity of the reaction and potentially life-threatening consequences.
rationale.incorrect: Administering diphenhydramine is a secondary intervention to address allergic symptoms, but it does not halt the underlying hemolytic process. Collecting a urine specimen is important for diagnostic purposes, but delaying cessation of the transfusion will exacerbate the reaction. Slowing the transfusion rate is contraindicated as it continues to expose the patient to the incompatible blood and will worsen the reaction.

answerBreakdown.explanation: Stopping the transfusion is the FIRST action to prevent further harm.
Diphenhydramine addresses allergic symptoms but does not stop hemolysis.
Urine collection is diagnostic but delays immediate intervention.
Slowing the transfusion prolongs exposure to incompatible blood.

clinicalPearls: Acute hemolytic transfusion reactions are medical emergencies requiring immediate cessation of the transfusion.
Lower back pain during a transfusion is a classic sign of a hemolytic reaction.
Always double-check blood compatibility before initiating a transfusion.

questionTrap.trap: Nurses may be tempted to administer medications first, but stopping the transfusion is the absolute priority.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize actions that address the root cause of the problem and prevent further harm before addressing symptoms.

mnemonic.title: STOP the Transfusion
mnemonic.expansion: S: Stop the transfusion immediately. T: Take the blood and tubing down. O: Obtain vital signs. P: Provider notification.
